Indeed, most scholars of comparative politics regard the US system, particularly its federal aspects, as one with many points at which minority factions can veto majoritarian politics (Lijphart, 2008; Stepan, 2001).
Barker’s (2009) analysis nicely captures how variation in the institutional dynamics of the states can exacerbate or mitigate these biases.

See Gonzalez v. Raich, 545 US 1 (2005), ruling that the US Congress can criminalize marijuana even where states, in this case California, had approved its use for medical purposes, and the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act, Public Law 109–92 (2005), banning liability lawsuits against gun manufacturers in federal courts (in response to such lawsuits from nearly 30 cities in the USA).

Many states in the USA have passed pre-emption laws that bar local governments in the state from enacting gun control legislation that is stricter than policy at the state level. Similarly, the 1994 crime bill passed by Congress included funding for new prison construction and other state projects but this money was tied to ‘truth in sentencing’ legislation which required states to ratchet up the time offenders serve before they are eligible for parole. A powerful recent example of the disconnect between public views and actual policy is the high levels of support for stricter gun control policies in the wake of the horrific mass murder of small children in Connecticut in 2012. Translating such views into policy, however, means navigating a highly fragmented set of political institutions at the state and national levels.
See Schattschneider (1960: 66): ‘The definition of the alternatives [in public policy] is the supreme instrument of power.’

Ballot initiatives and referenda on policy issues are further aspects of the US system that are often cited as evidence of its hyper-democratized politics (Zimring et al., 2001). But referenda are notorious for low and skewed voter turnout, often as a result of preference intensity that does not reflect the median voter and substantially lopsided funding by proponents or opponents of the referendum. It is not clear what makes them more democratic than legislative decisions.

The Rodney King incident involved a high-speed car chase with the Los Angeles Police Department, which eventually resulted in King’s car being blocked by police cars at a freeway exit. King was subsequently beaten by LAPD officers, who were eventually charged with use of excessive force. The incident became widely known because of a videotape by a bystander that had recorded the beating. On 29 April 1992, the officers were acquitted of all charges. The incident was the subject of one congressional hearing in 1992. House of Representatives, Judiciary Committee, March 1992, H521–21.

Recent research suggests that even those who are not particularly affected by high rates of violence are broadly supportive of preventive policy efforts and first-time offender leniency (see Roberts et al., 2003). Similarly, a plausible interpretation of the counter-intuitive finding in Cooney and Burt (2008), that punishment is less severe when homicide is more prevalent, is that higher frequency of deviance may mean that the distribution of communities from which perpetrators emerge is broader, including those with political voice, representation and power, who do not wish to see exceedingly harsh punishment imposed on members of their own community.

bio.title: Author biography
bio.p: Lisa L Miller is an Associate Professor of Political Science at Rutgers University. She earned her PhD from the University of Washington in 1999. Her research interests are in law and social policy, constitutionalism, racial inequality and crime and punishment. Her most recent book, The Perils of Federalism: Race, Poverty and Crime Control (Oxford, 2008), explored the relationship between the peculiar style of American federalism and the substantial inequalities in criminal victimization and punishment across racial groups in the USA. She has written extensively on the development of crime and justice policy and legal frameworks in the USA with her work appearing in Law and Society Review, Law and Social Inquiry, Perspectives on Politics, the British Journal of Criminology, Policy Studies Journal, among others.
